title: 109_s206
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail Designation Act". The purpose of the Act is to designate the Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail. Congress finds that at the end of the last Ice Age, cataclysmic floods occurred in the northwest region of the United States, leaving dramatic features on the landscape. Geological features of exceptional value to illustrate this phenomenon are present on various types of land in the region. In 2001, a study team endorsed the establishment of an Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail. The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail was designated to recognize the national significance of the cataclysmic floods at the end of the last Ice Age in the northwest region of the United States. Its purpose is to enable the public to view, experience, and learn about the features and story of the floods through collaborative efforts of public and private entities in Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon. The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail recognizes cataclysmic floods in the northwest US during the last Ice Age. It allows public access to learn about the floods through collaborative efforts in Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon. The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail is designated to showcase the significant natural and cultural features of the Ice Age floods. The trail follows public roads and highways, with the route depicted on a map that can be revised by the Secretary. The map for the Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail must be available for public inspection at National Park Service offices. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary administers the Trail through the National Park Service, with a Trail Management Office for coordination. Interpretive facilities can be built in partnership with other entities. A management plan must be developed within 3 years. The Secretary administers the Trail through the National Park Service, with a Trail Management Office for coordination. Interpretive facilities can be built in partnership with other entities. Within 3 years, a cooperative management and interpretation plan for the Trail must be prepared in consultation with various stakeholders to confirm and expand on the inventory of flood features. The Trail Management Office coordinates the Trail's administration. Within 3 years, a plan must be prepared to improve feature descriptions, reevaluate interpretive potential, modify the map, and develop interpretive facilities and programs. The Secretary may enter into cooperative management agreements with officials in Montana, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon to facilitate development and coordination of activities related to the Trail. The Trail is considered a unit of the National Park System for this purpose. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public or private entities to carry out the Act. This Act does not require private property owners to allow public access or modify any laws regarding public access to private land. Designation of the Trail does not create liability for private property owners for injuries on their property. Authorization of appropriations for this Act allows for necessary funds to be appropriated, with a limit of $12,000,000 for Trail development. Passed by the Senate on November 16, 2005.
